info_3: it wouldn't work w/ my system, so i sent it back and got another

title: SFSG, with small caveat
author: KatKit103
info_3: I was looking for an inexpensive replacement thermostat with a true temperature swing setting, since with the old one our heat pump was cycling too frequently for optimal efficiency and longevity. This seems like an answer. Other than it's tweakability, it is relatively basic (don't really need seven day programming or a touchscreen) but it gets the job done. Installation took a little longer due to the different design and terminal layout, but I certainly didn't need a service call from someone looking to install a premium model.It was a little hard to separate from the base. Good that I only need batteries as backup, so decent ones should last awhile. And although it will briefly drift +/- a degree from the setpoint (due partly to my +/- 0.5 swing), so far operation is smooth. A 'possible' flaw in really cold weather is the auxiliary heat control: An adjustable offset that prevents AUX until the temperature is X degrees below the setpoint. Good if you want to manually bump the temperature slightly without using more expensive AUX. Maybe not so good if the heat pump alone can't maintain the setpoint, and room temp drops 2+ degrees before supplemental heat engages. That should be rare around here, and occasional adjustment shouldn't be bothersome. Speaking of minimizing AUX, enabling "smart recovery"/"early recovery" is wise when using a setback (which should also be modest for a standard heat pump) unless it's smaller than the offset.I do wonder if the sensor is a bit slow, as it takes time for it to re-equilibrate with room temperature after the backlight circuit warms it up. The switches are somewhat small and cheapish feeling compared to my old stat. The access door is also on the thin side (it'd likely take a mm more plastic for a more solid unit), and the double hinge makes it slightly awkward to shut if you let it fall below a ~90 degree angle. Perhaps not ideal for families that frequently adjust their stat, but we don't mess with it much. So if we get several years out of this and it doesn't screw up, I'll be happy. To me, it's better than paying more for the 'other' brand that is less adjustable and only has a 1 year warranty in it's consumer line.As a semi-contientous Amazonian, I will try to edit my review if something really unsatisfactory arises.Update:  So went through a summer, and another winter. It would be nice if a swing could be set separately for cool and heat mode. Or ideally, it would be nice to find a t-stat that can properly adjust cycle times even in less than perfect installations. Heat isn't always evenly distributed, and some days waiting for a full +/- 0.5/1 degree total swing can leave floors and ductwork a bit chilly (maybe a house issue). Conversely, during the cooling season a wider swing can be better for efficiency and dehumidification.

title: Very displeased
author: Melissa
info_3: Not good.... I ended up having to invite an AC friend to come look at it and he stated they are no good and not worth it...

title: it LOCKS!!! That's what I needed, so I'm happy
author: Gabrielle LeBlanc
info_3: This thermostat works great and was easy to program. One VITAL note: I deliberately went looking for a LOCKABLE thermostat, because family members kept cranking up the heat to ridiculous levels, like 78 F or 86 F. This thermostat DOES have a lock on it. The funny thing is, the locking code is NOT a secret PIN that you get to pick, it's a code that is provided to the buyer, and it is the SAME code for every single one of these thermostats, and it's available in the on-line literature!!!! So I don't know how much use this would be for a landlord trying to keep tenants from cranking up the heat, because any reasonably resourceful adult could figure out where to find the code -or anyone who's every owned this thermostat before would know. But for my purpose -preventing my kids from cranking up the heat- it works just fine and is doing exactly what I wanted it to, so I'm happy

title: Satisfied with Lux Products
author: denny1937
info_3: Some of the blame for my disappointment was caused by me. I took the specifications at face value. I simply wanted to be able to adjust the "temperature swing" ie, how much the temperature had to come up before it turned off the heat request. Most thermostats have a very narrow setting, something like .1 degree F(or less) With my system the heater would cycle every 8 minutes. I wanted .5 degree F. The TX500U literature states the "temperature swing" use user defined from .25 to 2.00 F. What is TRUE is that this is the case ONLY if you have a Heat Pump as a primary source and a Electric/gas source as a secondary. My system is single gas fired only.UPDATE as of May 7, 2014. Lux Products worked with me and solved my problem by supplying a model TX9600TS unit. It works very well.The original problem was that I purchased a model TX500U. the supplier did not have that unit but shipped me a TX500Ua, notice the lowercase a . I assume that the shipper does not know that there is difference between the "Ua" and the "U" . The Ua does not have a swing setting that I wanted. Lux products supplied a TX9600TS that has the options that I wanted.To sum up the folks at Lux were very helpful and made sure that I was satisfied.

title: Great Thermostat
author: Southplank
info_3: I'm happy with this thermostat. It works well and is easy to see without my reading glasses. Amazon price was half of my local home center price. I don't know if its my imagination or what, but the room temperature seems more steady. It could very well be, our old digital thermostat was 25 years old. While I found installation easy and straight forward, I would say this is not a project for the the average do-it-yourselfer, especially if you have heat+AC wiring and are electrically challenged. The problem for some may be that the labeling and wire colors on your old thermostat terminals may not match the new one. It helps to understand how thermostat systems work so you can be sure you are connecting it correctly. If you are not sure if you can do this, download the instruction manual from Lux and open up your old thermostat. If the installation wiring charts make sense and you are certain you identified all of your wires correctly, go ahead and buy this and install it yourself.This is a small challenge to program, you need to read the instructions carefully. If you figured out the wiring, you can certainly get through the programming. Once you 'get it', its not that bad. There is a copy function to copy one day to another to speed things up. Keep the instructions handy because you won't remember how to reprogram it when you need to change the program. Speaking of instructions, it comes with a sheet, but you can download the full 30+ page manual.Some reviewers mentioned pulling the whole unit off the wall when opening the front panel. They are certainly putting their finger in the wrong spot. The design of the plastic housing does make it confusing the first time, but once you see the correct way, opening the front panel is effortless.

title: Easy installation
author: Sadie
info_3: Working very well for us. Installation was pretty straight forward and although my husband (mechanic) installed it, I watched and we both agreed I could have done it myself (I'm a secretary). We haven't tried any of the special functions like changing how often it turns on or off. We only have it hooked up to a basic central air system. Haven't tried the vacation settings. I HAVE used the override function when I was off work one day and it worked how I expected it to, unlike the other thermostat we have.I have only two complains. 1.) It does not come with a complete instruction manual. Trying to set M-F at the same schedule without having to do each day individually is easy... as long as you understand how the function works. Without the instructions explaining it, it didn't work how I expected it to. I don't have a computer at home and had to use my phone to search the website. It was mostly just a pain to find. 2.) There is a very audible CLICK when the thermostat turns the AC on or off. The thermostat is at the top of the stairs, the living room is down the stairs and around the corner. I can hear it from the couch while watching TV at a low volume. No exaggeration.

title: Eating up batteries
author: Tricia
info_3: This worked very well for 2.5 years on one or two pairs of batteries, but now it churns through a new set of batteries every 2-3 weeks.  At first I blamed my Amazon-brand batteries, but I switched to Duracell and continue having the same problem.Note that this isn't an issue of being unable to reset the low battery indicator light that others have mentioned - I've let the indicator message flash for a few days and the batteries actually run out, then I install new ones and everything looks great for about a week.My old programmable thermostat lasted 12+ years before I switched it out with this one, so I'm quite disappointed with this short lifespan.

title: Works great, but has some flaws.
author: negativezero
info_3: It worked out of the box, took about 15 minutes to replace the old analog thermostat with this one. The temperature scheduling features work nicely, and the battery life has been good so far. My only gripe is with the total lockout feature, because it's not a total lockout feature, and there is little to no security to it. To bypass, all someone has to do is find the manual and locate the easy instructions to bypass the lockout.In addition, the product doesn't come with the full manual, only a basic one. To get the full manual, you have to go their web-site and download the PDF. This is fine and dandy; however, the desktop and mobile sites don't even have the same product list, and this model didn't even have this model and using the desktop site on a mobile device won't work. I had to use my main PC, download the manual, send it to my phone, just so I could reference it while setting up the scheduling and security.And to Lux, hire a real developer to fix your site.

title: It was fine for over a year then started giving Lo ...
author: Mom2Bear
info_3: Update: Contacted customer service and had no problem getting the product replaced.I bought the unit April 2015. It has worked fine until a couple of months ago started giving Lo Battery warning. We changed the battery, and a few days later the warning again. I even bought a new set of duracell batteries and again it only "lasted" a few days.  My husband tested the batteries and they are good. I come to read the comments and find other customers with same issue, but at least they got 2.5 years without the problem, for me is more like 1.5 if you count when the problem started.  It should have lasted longer.

title: Returned it because it does not have adjustable Swing
author: Alexander White
info_3: FYI: If like me you want a thermostat with adjustable swing, the version I received in June 2017 is the TX500Uc and it does not have adjustable swing. Moreover, this thermostat comes in a package labeled as TX500U. Nothing on the outside tells you that you might, in fact, have one of the variants: a, b, c , etc. Not till you cut open the package and flip open the door do you find out that what you bought is not what you thought. This amounts to poor and misleading marketing. Amazon needs to do better here. Opening the thermostat to insert batteries is also much harder than it is with my older Lux  TX1500, which has served me well for 15y years so far.

title: Failed during the warranty, but got a replacement
author: gWiz
info_3: I originally bought this thermostat over other thermostats because it looked like nice and simple and promised easy programming.  It turned out to be easy to set up and program.  It has a nice backlit display with the temperature in a larger readable size.  After about two years, I got the low battery indicator and replaced the batteries.The low battery indicator didn't go away. I tried hardware reset, cleaning the contacts, checking the battery voltage  and got the same low battery indicator.  I then figured that the thermostat had just gone bad and I had nothing to loose, so I removed the screws on the PC board and looked at the other sided for a bad component, particularly a bad capacitor.  I didn't find it at first, but then I found something that looked like a tiny battery that had tiny specs of blue corrosion on it.In my online searches, I came across the fact that this thermostat has a 3 year warranty, so I called the Lux techline.  I told them what the problem was and what I saw and they sent me a new thermostat.  I am happy again.With the new thermostat in place and working, I looked at the faulty thermostat with the low battery indicator and removed the bad tiny battery and found out that it is actually a capacitor that saves the memory when changing the regular AA batteries.  I found the part number for the capacitor, (it is a SM 3R3 703, 70mF, 3.3volts) and planned on ordering it.  Just to keep things together while I waited for the order to get placed and the part to come in, I put the thermostat back together with the AA batteries.  The display now gave me a full battery indication.  So, perhaps, just removing this tiny battery/capacitor will allow it to get around the problem.I will install the capacitor so that the program can be saved when changing the batteries or when handling the thermostat and the AA batteries get jostled.It was disappointing that the capacitor/battery failed so soon, however, getting a replacement under warranty softened the disappointment and now finding a work around will allow me to replace my upstairs thermostat, so that we have the same easy to program thermostat both upstairs and downstairs.My expectation is that Lux has already (or will soon) recognized that the capacitor is failing early and correct it.  Based on this experience, I would recommend it.

title: Pretty easy to use
author: foradrive
info_3: Decided to update our 20 year old non-programmable thermostat. Did a bit of research and this one from Lux stood out. It has a large easy to see display with backlight, is programmable for all seven separate days with four time zones per day, and works even with heat pumps.And it's very reasonably priced.We have geo-thermal heat and cooling, and this works perfectly. The wiring up part worried me, but I found the included diagram that matched mine, added the extra jumper wire as depicted, and was in business.It's great to be able to see the display from far away, and even better to know we're saving energy by having it reduce heating while we're away, sleeping, etc.It's easy to override the program if you need to. This thermostat can do a lot if you want to learn all of its capabilities.

title: Battery issue. Barely a year
author: K. Eckley
info_3: So it worked great for about 11 months. Then I started noticing that heat wasn't coming on as programmed. Energizer batteries showed about 50%. I programmed it all over again and then noticed the time was not correct. Odd. So,I set the current time and date.  Few hours later I look at the display and the time is wrong again. I replaced batteries with brand new energizer ones. To my surprise.....the battery indicator showed still 50%. WTF? I watched the display because the time is always wrong. As I'm watching .... the time is advancing by one minute every 12 seconds. Weird. I emailed support a bit ago and will call in the am. I purchased Jan.2017. Just a year ago. Model TX500Uc

title: Love It
author: Smileyface
info_3: I owned a Lux 610 unit since 2002.it wasn't back lit which was a pain.It was still working fine,but I decided to upgrade to the TX500e,It took me about 30 minutes to Install.The back lit works for ten seconds when you push any button( you have to push the button again if you want to change something)I've had this for a week and I live it!Works on 2 AA alkaline batteries and your power source(if you have one)I called Lux support before I bought this and when I received it(I had some questions) I recommend Lux(I'm NOT a Honeywell Fan)

title: Works great for only 1.5 years.
author: Alex Y
info_3: Excellent controller but read my update. Works great and looks very nice. I am using 2 rechargeable AA ni-mh batteries (Eneloops) and they have lasted for over a year. Much better than other controllers that use AAA batteries which lasted for only a few months.Update 5/1/2017:  Been using this now for 1 year and 7 months and it is showing the signs of low battery with fresh new / recharged batteries. Time to look for a new one.Update 5/9/2017:  Received new replacement unit from LUX because the unit has a 3 year warranty and mine died after 1.5 years. All is good again!!!

title: Lots of efficiency settings for heatpumps
author: whatever
info_3: Only a few days but the heat pump no longer goes to aux/emergency heat regularly or cycles every couple minutes like the honeywells these replaced.  These allow a swing selection of 1 to 9 degrees or so before the unit will kick on. So instead of the unit cycling back on like the honeywell when the temp drops 1/2 degree which is just minutes in extremely cold weather you can set it to let it drop a couple degree first.  Longer cycles for efficiency. Also allows you to set a number of degrees before aux/emergency kicks in. For example if you can set that function to 5 degrees the aux heat won't kick in unless there is a 5 degree or more gap between set temp and current, even then if it's programmed it will anticipate and start early. That setting saves money by anticipating the temp required in the AM for example and starts early so it reaches the temp without kicking on the aux heat. Aux will still kick in if primary stage can't maintain set temp and drops below your programmed kick in gap. I'm sure I didn't use the proper terms but I wish I'd research before I got the honeywells. They killed my electric bill with aux heat and short cycles before I finally realized they were the problem.

title: DO NOT BUT THIS THERMOSTAT!!!
author: C. J. Myers
info_3: Purchased this to replace a Honeywell nonprogramable stat. This works on heat pumps. It has 4 different temperature timings per day & I love the adjustable dead band (swing temperature - change in sensed temperature to turn heat/air on & off). Many new thermostats have a fixed dead band of 1 Deg F (cooling on 0.5 Deg F above set point & cooling off 0.5 Deg F below set point). They do this in an effort to maintain a more uniform & constant temperature, but it causes your unit to run more often & for shorter time periods. It's easy to program with the enclosed paperwork & it is easy to temporarily override programmed temperature. The backlit display works well & the filter monitor is a good reminder to change the filter (and the filter monitor hour setting is also adjustable). The display shows temperature, temperature set point, heat or cool mode, filter life remaining, time, day of week and programmed time mode (morn, day, eve, night). It has early recovery feature & battery backup. It does not automatically change between heat & cool...must be done manually with a switch, but that is what I wanted.UPDATE:  Although this thermostat has a lot of nice features, DO NOT BUT IT!!!!  The thermostat went bad after 2 years (Thermostat showed batteries were dead even with new alkaline batteries). Contacted company and they were very polite and helpful. The sent me a new thermostat for free, and I had to ship the defective thermostat back. They said that they were mailing me a new thermostat, but they would not do this again. The replacement thermostat lasted about 6 months, then the display showed ER, I attached a picture. The replacement thermostat malfunctioned on a 25 Deg F day in January! I was an HVAC mechanic for 21 years. Save yourself the headache and purchase another brand of thermostat. I purchased a Honeywell 5-2 on Amazon for $39.95. You have been warned!!

title: I Am So Glad That I Upgraded To Lux!
author: Yorima
info_3: I ordered this Lux product after reading the reviews.  I am happy to say that the installation was easy after having watched some Youtub videos so I could determine just how old and ancient my analog thermostat was.  The price of this thermostat was great and as mentioned previously, the installation was effortless as it took me about  fifteen to twenty minutes to install.  The only challenge is programmi!ng the darn thing but otherwise it once you have done that, you are good to go.  I should also note, that my electric bill went down because the digital is more accurate than my analog thermostat was so while many people had noted this in their comments I was not sure that I would see the difference so quickly but I did and I was actually surprised when I received my electric bill.  Now, I sit back and think about how a contractor offered to upgrade my prehistoric analog thermostat to a digital for almost three hundred dollars a few years ago!  Imagine that!  I recommend this product.

title: How to fix low battery
author: Justa Girl
info_3: I had 2 of these thermostasts and loved them for many months before getting the blinking "LO BATT" message that everyone is mentioning. Real pain that changing the batteries or using reset button didn't stop the message. I contacted customer service who emailed me:"please put the switch in the off position and hold the up and down button together and press the HW reset down until you see all zero's on the display"That worked right away for one of mine, for the other one it didn't but I tried removing the (new) batteries and doing the same thing and then it worked for that one too.I am glad it worked as I really like the thermostat, but I am annoyed that it seems a real problem of this unit and I shouldn't have to contact them, wait two days for customer service to respond, & then apply the fix. I am pretty sure it will happen again when the batteries get low and by then I will be trying to remember how to fix it.

title: Great thermostat, far superior to digital Honeywell models, easy to program
author: TJ
info_3: I really like this thermostat, it's far better than digital Honeywell models. Unlike Honeywell, this LUX has essential features like delay for unit protection, temperature swing settings Incase it comes on too often or too little, a Common power connection so you can power it from the AC unit and use the batteries only for backup purposes, filter reminder, and backlit display. My AC unit is actually running much better since I installed this LUX thermostat, it seems to kick on and off smoother.

title: This is an excellent programmable thermostat
author: Peter from Maine
info_3: This is an excellent programmable thermostat. Easy to install and easy to use.  I especially like the fact that it lights up the display when you push one of the buttons. I would give it an excellent review even without my service experience.Had a problem after almost two years with the battery indicator. Even after changing the batteries (they recommend Duracell or Everready) and even using the system reset, the indicator showed low and then it began flashing a lo indicator.Point is that I emailed LUX at their tech support at techsupport@luxproducts.com and received an immediate reply.  This was on a Monday. On Friday I received a replacement thermostat.  OUTSTANDING service commitment!

title: Works great
author: K. Hurley
info_3: So far this thermostat is working perfect. It is so nice to wake up to a warm house. I thought the directions ware a bit confusing. I had a little trouble figuring out how to set up the different temperature changes but my son figured it out and got it set up. I got this because I wanted to try to save money during the winter by turning the temperature back to 65 at night.  It seems to be working perfectly so far.

title: Not likely to last the warranty period.
author: Reviewer_Ken
info_3: This is a real piece of C***.  I bought 2 of them.  The first failed about 18 months in.  "SOMETIMES" the heat would not turn on.  Most of the time it worked ok.  Get up at 6 am and find out the temps are in the 50's and you will not be pleased.They come with a 3 year warranty so I called the company and they gladly sent me another.The second original started getting bad after about 2.5 years.  Again they agreed to send me a replacement, but this time it never came (after a month of waiting) and I was forced to get a new one right away once the old one died completely.Don't expect these to last more than a year or two.

title: Good little thermostat
author: Jaber
info_3: I got this to replace an aging 15 year old programmable unit.  Excellent for the price.  The display has large characters, and is bright and easy to read in a dark hallway. This is important when you wake up at 3AM and want to adjust the temperature without looking for your glasses and flicking on a light.It uses simple daily time-based programming which is perfectly fine for me.  It's seems that this unit is a bit more conservative than the previous one regarding the delay before turning on or off the AC/Heat when the appropriate temperature is reached. I'm fine with this, perhaps it will save a little in my energy cost.

title: Nice and easy to use
author: HFL
info_3: I really like these Lux programmable thermostats, I know have three of these and two of their higher end versions.  The only issue I've had with this particular model is battery life.  The first two I set up would eat up batteries in a few months.  Lux customer service responded by sending me two new ones, updated models with return postage for the first two.  The replacements are better, batteries last much longer.

title: My Third Lux 7-Day Programmable Thermostat
author: David Swan
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is the third Lux Universal 7-Day Programmable Thermostat I?™ve bought. The reason I?™ve bought so many is because, unfortunately, I keep moving and I don?™t have the nerve to take the thermostat with me. The reason I initially bought this one is to save money on heating. I lived in Ohio and now Colorado and it makes all the sense in the world to have the temperature set lower at night and it?™s a pain to set it every day. What I do with the Lux is set the thermostat to heat up about half an hour before I get out of bed and then go down after I generally go to work again and then up again prior to returning home. That way the temperature is always comfortable without keeping the heat on all day. I?™ll let others debate whether having the temperature go up and down four times a day actually saves on heating bills but I?™m not talking huge temperature swings.The one nagging annoyance is when my routine is broken. If, for instance, I take a week off I now need to reset five days and that can take some time. It would also be nice if you could change more than one day at a time. During the work week all the four daily temperature changes are the same time and same temperature but I have to go through each day one at a time and set them. It would be cool if you had wireless access to the thermostat and could set the temperature using a smartphone app or tablet with a more user friendly interface. It would assuredly raise the price but I?™d be willing to pay the extra for the convenience.So I see possible improvements but I wouldn?™t keep coming back to the Lux if I didn?™t think it was a good product. I guess saying I bought three is endorsement enough.

title: Battery power problem!
author: scotty
info_3: The TX9100 is a piece of junk.  It lasted less than 2 years.  Slowly but surely, the battery replacements, and three succeeding replacements died out.  On the fourth battery replacement, it wouldn't come alive at all.  This problem is discussed all over  the internet, and is one of the reasons why 14% of the Amazon customers give it a one star rating.  I am going to take it outside and bash it with a sledgehammer; except for the new batteries which I will recover.  Don't waste your money.

title: Lux Thermostats
author: Tom T
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is a review of the Lux TX9100U 7 Day Programmable Thermostat. I am replacing the Lux TX1500E that I have had for a few years. I also have a Lux TX500 Uc that I will put into my shop, so... I will refer to each one at times.Since I already had a Lux programmable thermostat installed it was very easy to replace it with the new thermostat. I removed the old one after writing down the wire colors and where they were attached on the old thermostat. This was done just in case the new one did not work properly.I had the wires labeled previously. The new thermostat came with a sheet of labels to do this also.The new thermostat attached to the same screw holes in the wall as the old one. The size of the unit was slightly different so that a very small bit of painting touch up will be required on the wall. It attached securely and tight.Here is the first problem: the screw heads for thermostat/furnace wires, which work with either slot or phillips, are so small that I had to get my wife to locate her sewing machine tools.She had a very tiny screw driver to unscrew the thermostat wire attachment screws. There was not a screw driver in my shop that was small enough. I attached the wires, put in the batteries, and snapped the thermostat onto the mounting plate.Programming the 4 different times for the seven days went well and easily except that the copying of one day to the next had no clear directions, which I found to be problem two. This was copying the same settings from one day to the next without having to go through the whole procedure. The instructions provided with the thermostat were unclear. I decide to call Lux to find out how they were for customer service. I got a recording which said to leave my name and number and they would call back within 24 hours. This is better than being on hold for an extended period of time, but not as good as a Person. They gave out the web site and I found clearer directions there and was able to copy my daily program to another day without having to go through the four period day programming.I tested the cooling and heating and all worked fine. I should mention that it is good to shut the breaker off for the furnace before starting the removal of the old thermostat. This is not that you will get electrocuted from 24v, but rather to keep from blowing a fuse in the 24v furnace board.One thing I really liked about my old thermostat, the TX1500E was that the thermostat temperature programming procedure was printed right inside the thermostat cover, very handy. If I decide to reprogram the new one in 6 months, I will have certainly forgotten how to do it and will have to go online or search for the directions in the file cabinet. I mentioned the other Lux TX500 Thermostat... it will be installed exactly the same and just will have slightly different programming features. Either one would have been fine for my house (2 stage furnace, one stage air). The advantage to using the programmable thermostat is a real savings in heat cost since there is no forgetting to change the temperature. Overall, I have always been happy with the quality of the Lux thermostats which is why I went with them a second time.I have never had the thermostat run by the furnace power, always used batteries, and I will likely have to get a furnace guy to hook that up properly if I decide to go away from the battery use.

title: Very easy installation, nice features
author: HK
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This Lux 7-Day programmable thermostat was super easy to install and set up. It offers a lot of features that I never thought about wanting, but am now glad to have. I've been using a very basic programmable thermostat for the last decade and was happy with the ability to create a simple schedule to control my heat pump. My old unit has been giving me problems lately (buttons difficult to push) so I looked forward to installing a new one.Some of the features I like about this unit are:- Large display is easy to read (no need to fumble for my glasses in the middle of the night)- Back-light is bright and attractive blue- Filter monitor reminds me to change the filter, something I always forget- Clear installation instructions make it easy (I'm a grandma and it was a breeze)- Ability to program different temps for night, when I'm tucked in and my comfort needs changeIt wobbles a little, but so did my old thermostat. Overall, I'm very happy with this thermostat. It helps simplify a basic task, and I'm all for that.

title: Saves us up to $40.00 per month now...
author: Candace
info_3: We have been using this for several months now. Our old thermostat just had one setting. So it was always coming on when we weren?™t home because nobody thinks to turn off the thermostat every single day before the leave for work. This is such a great price for how many settings it has. My power bill has gone down significantly. Saving me nearly $40.00 per month. It?™s exactly what we needed in our home and didn?™t cost an arm and a leg to obtain.

title: Works well, simple and clean looking
author: eric m.
info_2: Pattern: 5-1-1 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: I got this to replace my old Honeywell thermostat which had no programming ability. This unit was super easy to install and program. I had it up and running in just a few minutes. I don't have air conditioning in my house but I do have central heating and we are gone for much of the day so it's nice to program the unit to come on shortly before we return from work. I also have it warm up in the mornings before work. It's worked perfectly with just one small annoyance. This may be common with modern thermostats, but if you want to override the setting and turn on the heat, you need to adjust the temperature at least 2 degrees higher or nothing will happen. In our house, it's fairly small and we have the temperature dialed in exactly where we want it but sometimes we just want it half a degree warmer. So it's a little annoying to have to turn it up 2 degrees higher and then remember to turn it down later or it will be too hot. Kind of a silly thing but other than that, this is a great unit at a good price. It looks great too. Very clean looking in our modern house.

title: Decent features for a budget thermostat
author: Gadget Geek
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: I've used and recommended Honeywell thermostats (usually the higher-end models) over the years.  This was my first experience with a product from Lux.  This review is for the Lux TX500U Universal 5-2 Programmable Thermostat.So you're shopping for a thermostat.  A programmable thermostat is absolutely the way to go and can save you hundreds of dollars a year in heating/cooling costs.  With a programmable thermostat, you can set it to heat/cool at certain times of day to maintain a comfortable temperature at home.  This helps as when you are typically at work, the thermostat can be set to turn off, saving you power and money.  Which one you decide to purchase should depend on your typical habits.For basic needs, there are the 5-2 programmable thermostats (5 weekday, 2 weekend) meaning that it would have certain settings for the 5-weekdays, and a different setting for the 2-day weekend.  If you have more complex schedules, there are also 5-1-1 (5 weekday, Saturday, and Sunday), or 7-day (each day has its own settings).  For more sophisticated needs, you can splurge on ones that can be programmed over wi-fi, touch screens, color screens, or the Tesla of thermostats -- the Nest.This Lux product is as basic as you can get it, for those with basic needs and on a budget.Based on my limited use so far, heres what I thought of the systemPROS:- Backlit display (press any button to have display lit up).  However, the buttons do not light up.- Programmable -- 5weekday 2weekend.  You can program 2 or 4 periods per program set.- Can be used in many different HVAC systems/configurations (except electric baseboard heat)- Smart recovery -- reach your desired temperature by a set time- Lockout features -- prevent people from fiddling with the settings- System Control Duration -- This allows you to set how frequently the system is allowed to turn ON when it is in a programmed temperature mode.  Contrast this to temperature swing settings that many other thermostats use, this could decrease the # of times the system turns on.CONS:- Not that intuitive to setup.  The basic installation guide lacked detail.- Made of flimsy plastic.  The latched panel looks like it can easily be broken off.- Many keys hidden behind the panel.- Backup battery compartment can only be accessed from the back.  Inconvenient when you need to replace it.- Buttons do not light up.While this thermostat is far from perfect, it is a decent thermostat for the price.

title: Easy to install.  Doing a great job of working to the program.
author: myotherself
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: From the instruction sheet:  This thermostat can be used with most 24 volt:  gas, oil, Millivolt, electric heating and cooling systems, including heat pumps with an aux/emerg heat element.  It cannot be used with:  120/240 volt heating elements (without a transformer), or on heat pumps that have two compressor stages (Y2).  Ask your dealer for other Lux thermostats to control those systems.This Lux TX500U Programmable thermostat was easy to install and also easy to program for our heating and cooling system.  We have natural gas heat and this thermostat controls the temperature in the downstairs of our home.  I went to the Lux company website and watched a video of how to install the thermostat.  I also spoke with the man who keeps my systems running and got a little advice from him, but we did not have any trouble with the installation of the unit.  The advice we got was to turn off the breakers for both of our heating/cooling units as well as to unplug them both in the attic.  This was probably more caution than we needed, but we did it anyway.One of the things I really liked about this unit right away was that I could hold it in my hand and perform all the programming after installing the two AA batteries (recommended by manufacturer to use Energizer or Duracell Alkaline ONLY).  This made it much easier to see what I was doing.  The controls on the front of the panel are 1) Heat/Off/Cool; 2) Auto/On Fan; 3) Multi-function Set slide switch; 4) Up/Down buttons; 5) Emergency button; and 6) Next button.  These are the buttons you will use when programming your unit.  There are nine configurations for this unit.  They are:  1) Clock (12 hour default or 24 hour military;  2)  Temp. scale (Farenheit or Celcius; 3) Thermostat type (programmable or manual); 4) Period quality (4P default - morn, day, eve, nite) or 2P (day and nite); 5) Early Recovery (Off default) temp values start at the exact period start time; 6) System mode (Furn default) or HP for heat pump; 7) Delay (5 default - furnace waits 5 minutes after previous run to come back on; 8) Temp Swing (set between 1-9 times of operation per hour with 3-6 most commonly used); 9) Stage-2 offset (2 default) value 0-9 will determine degrees from set point temp for system to turn on again.  These values are set once and probably will not be re-set after you find how accurate your thermostat is.  I have gone back and changed the Stage-2 offset from the default setting to #4 because this thermostat is so much more accurate than my old unit was.Once you set the day and time it is very easy to go through and set the program for Mon-Tues-Wed-Thurs-Fri, Sat, Sun with the time of day for each of the 4 possible times (morn, day, eve, nite) and the temperature for each using the up/down button with "next" setting the program before you move on to the next day/time/temp.  You can override the current program using the up/down buttons and the "hold" button.  The print and numbers are a little small on the unit, but you can tap up/down/or hold and the screen will light up long enough to see what the current program and temperature is.

title: so I'll have to put another two hole in my poor wall. 2
author: Konstantin S.
info_3: Just had it installed as a replacement for an old programmable thermostat where one of the buttons starter to stick (and of course they don't produce it anymore). Observations:1. Of course, old mounting holes in the walls (I have two pairs of them) don't match with the holes in this thermostat, so I'll have to put another two hole in my poor wall.2. The pictures are deceiving: they show nice blue screen which will appear only when you start pushing buttons; in normal condition the numbers on the screen will be not so bright and visible.3. Compartment for wires coming from the wall is pretty shallow, so you'll have to apply some effort with placing them so they don't get cut off or prevent the unit from closing.4. There is no external door for the battery compartment, so every time you need to replace the batteries - you'll need to take off the front part of the unit from the wall (and then deal with the wires again - see #3).When ordering, make sure to order LUX Universal Wallplate - there is a good chance the wall behind your old thermostat was not painted.

title: A great new thermostat
author: subwo
info_3: I purchased this to replace a TXE 500 that lasted 12 years.  It would have lasted longer but the green and yellow wire from thermostat shorted at the junction where it ties into the furnace. We noticed this when the blower stayed running when thermostat was off. Fixed that problem and noted that old thermostat would not work. So this was purchased at a great price compared to buying at big box home store.  I really like the backlight display and larger numbers on this model. Easy to install in the old holes for the screws or new holes can be made if not replacing a Lux thermostat.  Screws and plastic drywall anchors provided with thermostat.  Vacation hold.

title: Did not work for me me...
author: Victor
info_3: This was bought for me to replace an old 4-wire Lux thermostat. Only it didn't work. As far as I could tell, I wired it correctly. I suppose I could have made a mistake but I followed the wiring instructions. Not only did it not work for the heater but it also refused to work for a/c, which had been working with the old thermostat. It was returned to Amazon for a refund. We just purchased Lux TX100E 7-Day Programmable Thermostat and am hoping for better luck. Simple 4-wire to 4-wire installation.

title: Works fine for a single pipe steam heating system
author: K.Fischer
info_3: I use this to control a single pipe steam heating system. Installation was easy and programming was OK as well. I is a very slow heating system and the control feature of the temperature swing is very helpful. I put it on the lowest setting. I could not find instructions for the swing settings in the short Manuel but it was described well in the one I downloaded. The steam heating system stops but there is so much heat in the radiators that it gets a bit warmer. Most of the time it would not go 1Â°F over the set point, which is nice. With the commonly larger swing settings in most thermostats it is probably worse.I would welcome if the thermostat would have an anticipator control feature to precisely control the temperature. A runtime limiter would be nice as well. However, I could not find such a thing for a programmable thermostat.

title: Can't recommend
author: The Rick
info_3: Worked great for about 9 months. For the last month it flashes for "low batteries". Changed the batteries several times and tried 3 different brands of batteries to no effect. Programming has no memory so every time the batteries are changed it has to be reprogrammed.

title: Low Battery Indicator 4 Months After Installation!
author: Amazon Customer
info_3: Bought the TX9100U Feb 2, 2017 and by June 12, 2017 I am getting the "low battery" indicator. When I installed the thermostat I used brand new batteries so I was a little concerned that in 4 months the batteries would be low. I took the batteries out and they tested fine at 99%. I put new set in to clear the indicator now lets see how long before the low battery indicator reappears. But right now I am not happy with this thermostat and would not recommend it.

title: Died in Five Months
author: Gerald C.
info_3: What can you say about a thermostat you bought in May that died in November. Wasn't bad to program. Decent features. Could have used a backlight. But all moot when it lasted five months. Worse, only the heat function died, so I suckered into a technician service call to show me the thermostat was bad. Good when they work. But they need to get  credit for this lemon.

title: Buggy Hardware/Software
author: DrMom
info_3: We bought 2 TX9100U in June 2014. I thought I understood the swing feature due to an explanation found on one of the reviews. However, when the unit randomly stops working when its 20 degrees below its set temperature for more than 2 hours, that I can't understand. Whats worst, two of the days when it did stop working over the weekend, our pipes froze. On one of those days, it the pipes even burst. If it stopped working, the only way to turn the units back on is by flipping the switch to off and then back to its original setting. These random stops may have been occurring since its initial installation but I didn't notice since I wasn't the one using the rooms.

title: Works well for pellet stoves now
author: Dwinder
info_3: I'll admit I was originally very frustrated when I purchased this in 2013 to control a pellet stove. It was not controlling it properly, it was constantly short cycling which triggered the pellet stove to begin its cycle, then when the controller turned off 3 - 4 seconds later, the pellet stove would not immediately turn off. It wants to fill the bowl an be ready to ignite, but it would not ignite because it was no longer getting the signal from the controller. With the original version this would happen multiple times before the controller would be in a state to insist on igniting the pellets which worried me about how many pellets were in the pot. I immediately contacted LUX about this issue and they worked with me and got me the next revision which did work better... until recently.It started to flash the low battery symbol constantly. I would put new batteries in, and nothing would change. I put another set of batteries in...no change. I then checked the voltage level of the batteries and found them to be in prime condition. Once again I contacted LUX and they agreed to send out a replacement unit. That unit has now arrived and appears to be working even better than the last one. With revision b I would often hear one short cylce every once-in-a-while. I don't think I have noticed any yet.Pros:Controller now seems to be working very nicely.Customer Support was easy to work with.Easy to use.Easy to read display.Very nice to have a daily programmable controller instead of manually setting the temperature every morning and evening.Cons:It took a while the first time to convince LUX that there was an issue.Not good having a battery powered unit fail after 2 years. Fortunately it has a 3 year warranty.Customer support this second time was not good at replying to email messages. (phone conversations were the only way I got any information out of them). This is a stark contrast to 2013 where I had very good email conversations with one of their support technicians.

title: Good thermostat, though I ended up giving it to ...
author: Amazon Customer
info_3: Good thermostat, though I ended up giving it to my brother when I realized I needed a 7 day programmable one since Fridays are so different from the rest of my week (M-T) and Sundays are different from Saturdays. I kind of feel like there are not a lot of situations where a 5-2 is worth it compared to a 7 day one but the thermostat itself is solid, no complaints from me or from him.

title: Lux Seven Day Programmable Thermostat
author: Dr. Who
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: I did not expect much from this universal thermostat, but it was better than expected.  Instruction sheet came with the product which was fairly easy.  Going through the menu and set up was instinctive.  You can have a different setting for weekdays and theweekends.  Further on, you can have a two to four different setting throughout the day,  feature that may help you save on heating bills.  The bright blue display makes it easy to read.  It does need a change of battery when the indicator shows up, but it claims to be over 8,00o hours of use before it needs to. Features, as stated in the description all work with easy set up. This a good basic thermostat control that works and comes at a good price.

title: Malfunctioning after a year of use
author: RainbootedRobot
info_3: Not quite a year and the unit is repeatedly draining fresh batteries over the course of a week.

title: Defective Product
author: doug71300
info_3: I am a commercial heating and air-conditioning mechanic that has been in the business for 15 years and ordered these thermostats from amazon as they were cheaper than a comparable one at the wholesaler. I installed two of the TX500u thermostats at my dad's house. The instructions and programming were standard like most residential thermostats. His two systems were single stage heating and cooling with a standard 4 wire thermostat line. After two months of use the thermostats failed to maintained a set temperature. The hold button would not operate and would revert to different temperatures and would require resetting almost constantly. I finally ordered a two decent Honeywell thermostats and replaced the defective LUX ones. I am unsure of how these thermostats rate the many positive reviews on amazon. The thermostats also lack an auto changeover from heating to cooling when outside temperatures vary as they do in Texas. The thermostats claim a three year warranty and state that during this period you are required to return them to the retailer. Amazon does not accept returns after a short period of time and you must deal with LUX Products by email or by phone on their website for warranty. In closing, it would be best to purchase a thermostat at a retailer like Home Depot that can credit or exchange the defective products during the warranty period even if you have to pay a little bit more for them.

title: The support by Lux is poor. When you call they say leave a message ...
author: The Great Pine Tree
info_3: The support by Lux is poor. When you call they say leave a message and will call you back in about 24 hrs. If you have your thermostat installed and it does not work your in trouble.You need to send it back and buy one that has support for their products. Lux wants a person to stay home by the thermostat for at least 24 hrs in hopes they call. And no heat or cooling while your waiting. They called back after the 24 hrs but I was not home. I waited the 24 hrs but this is modern support today.After installing it the display would keep turning off. After removing with batteries in it it would turn back on. found they put the reset button above the wires. The wires were pressing and holding the reset button. Push the wires flat and it worked.The temperature degree delay works nicely. The blue color only comes on when you touch it. Disappointed with that also. Hopefully it will work a few years. If it breaks do not count on support.

title: So Much Nicer Than Old Analog Thermostat
author: SevereWX
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: I was skeptical of this thermostat after having read various negative reviews from several different websites. My reservations seem to have been unfounded, however. The thermostat comes with a helpful instruction sheet that shows how to wire it up from various types of heat and a/c units. Having an older American Standard system with several extra wires (which were unnecessary for an electronic thermostat) did make wiring this unit up a little more confusing than the majority of installations would likely be. Still, within 20 minutes I had everything up and running just fine. I was able to use the per-existing mounting holes from the old analog thermostat, which saved me a lot of hassle in having to drill new holes.The menu system is easy to use, and it is important to note during installation whether you have gas heat or heat pump. The thermostat defaults to gas, so if you have a heat pump, make sure to select the correct setting in the menu system before turning it on, or you'll have no heat.The swing setting adjustable, and is set too tight for my tastes. I do not like my air conditioning unit kicking on upwards of 6 times per hour just to maintain a perfect temperature at all times. Loosening the setting up to allow for a 1.5 degree swing in either direction still allowed me to maintain a comfortable house at all times, yet only has the air conditioner have to cycle twice per hour, hopefully prolonging it's lifespan since the on/off cycles cause the most wear and tear.The temperature settings can be adjusted for 4-different settings per each day of the week, 2-different settings per each day of the week, or a simple single temperature at all times. The flexibility this programming allows is great for just about any situation anyone would have need for.The display is easy to read, the temporary lighted display makes reading the thermostat in the dark a breeze, and the outer plate that covers most of the buttons and switches makes for a very clean and stylish installation.Needless to say I am very happy with this thermostat, it functions perfectly fine with my American Standard 'Heritage' system.

title: Excellent full feature thermostat but you must download the PDF manual first.
author: jack wilinsky
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: First of all, the three most important aspects to this(assuming you opened the package without bleeding to death) are the installation, prgramming and setting, and the features. We should start with the instructions. Enclosed we find an instruction sheet in English and one in Spanish. At the end of the instructions, we are told that these instructions are not complete and we should download the full instructions from their website. It would have been nice if they told us that at the beginning before we tried to figure out the strange references to switches that are not visible. It would also be nice if they actually enclosed a paper copy of the full instructions since it isn't much bigger than the short version. Once you get the PDF instruction manual things start to make much more sense. Actually, everything is explained well with just one oversight: there is no explanation how to open the front panel nor how to remove the back plate. OK, it isn't all that hard to figure out but when I have to exert considerable force(which you do, especially when it is new) I start to wonder if I am doing it correctly. So, to open the front panel(they show it open in the PDF) you pry it open from the top using the edge closest to you, otherwise you will remove the front assembly from the back plate. To remove the back plate, exert even force around the top and bottom, engaging the rear portion only. Since it takes a bit of force, be careful not to fumble with it once it all of a sudden comes apart, since there are connection pins(be careful not to bang into them and bend them; they are sturdy pins, though)and circuit components that could be damaged if you bang into them. The screws are inside after you remove the back plate(they don't tell you that ahead of time). Everything else is just fine and this is really easy to install and use. For example, one of the more difficult installations is to figure out how to install the simplest of cases: a two wire system, found in older homes! Often this simple case is overlooked and you could go crazy trying to figure out how to simplify the process down to just two wires. The instructions specifically tells you how to do it(use RH and W1, actually just W). So, you can program your heart out with this or just do a simple setup. Just be sure to download the PDF manual FIRST and follow it carefully and you should enjoy this thermostat. By the way, I don't see any type of "A" and "B" point settings, which would determine separate on and off temperature values. There is a paper included that explains(with confusing reference to obsolete models; this one is the newer model) it does this automatically. It monitors the on/off behavior for a few hours and determines the optimum on and off values for a given temperature setting, so it takes a few hours for this to settle into an optimum behavior. But there is a setting for "swing", which tells the device how tightly you want the on off temperatures to stick to the temperature setting. That will determine how frequently the heat(or cooling) goes on and off per hour.

title: Good control, without being complicated
author: Water Monkey
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: We replaced our old Lux thermostat (approx 10 yeears old with this one TX500U).  Our other unit was also a 5-2 unit.  If you are trying to decide between a 5-2, 5-1-1, or 7 day thermostat the basic question you need to ask yourself is, "How much programming do I want to have to do". 7 day units allow for the most control as each day is its own customizable program.  This works great if you have specific days in the week that vary widely in how you want to heat/cool your home.  The 5-2 unit is the most basic pattern as it gives you 2 programs M-F and Sat-Sun (the 5-1-1 unit treats Sat and Sun as separate programs and M-F as one). The price difference is only a few dollars, so I suggest getting the one that fits your lifestyle. Once you have decided on the type of thermostat, it's time to install.We were replacing an older unit so installation was simple; just mark which terminals each wire in the old system was going to, remove the old unit (including backing) and mount the new unit. I had no issues changing the unit, as they are all pretty similar.The Lux systems come with predefined periods of the day.  These are basically the number of times a day you can re-set the temp.  You have a choice between 2 or 4 periods.  We choose 4 periods to give us more flexibility.  The unit comes with factory defined times for those periods, but you can set them differently if needed. At this point you just set the temp for each time period for both weekdays and weekends.There are many nice features in the unit that most of us will leave at the factory defaults (delay, early recovery, swing...). You can look into them and decide if you want them changed.I am pleased with my unit.  It provides sufficient amount of control for us.  Initially I wanted to go with a 7 day controller, but scaled back once I realized our day-to-day schedule does not change much. I can see using this thermostat until I finally move to a smart thermostat

title: Spend $20 More to Get Away from this Low End Unit
author: Quality Man
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This review is for TX9100U (7-Day).  Note there are three different Lux models associated with this page: TX1500U, TX500U, and the TX9100U which can cause some confusion in the reviews here.I installed this on a rental property I own as the previous thermostat (different company) was getting old.  I do have a little experience with Lux as I have a unit in my own home that is about eight years old.Installation started good as there are helpful stickers to put on wires as you uninstalled the old unit.  The diagram showing popular wire configurations made it real easy for me.  For my setup, I was working with a heat pump.  I thought I was stuck for a moment but then I realized that a bridging wire was in the little plastic bag to bridge Y to W.  After I got the wires setup, I put the batteries in and popped the cover on.  Next I switched the power back on, and everything worked perfectly.Next was configuration and setup.  To my surprise, there is no diagram in the manual about the front panel!  The manual uses all text for describing this, and this greatly slowed the configuration stage.  The manual also calls the Temperature control area the "System Mode" switch.  I'd recommend the manual and the front panel labeling use consistent terminology.  After these little hiccups, I was able to get the unit setup as desired.This unit clearly feels like a budget thermostat.  The cover feels cheap and can be amazingly difficult to open.  How difficult?  I bent a finger nail trying to get the thing open -- and I have very short nails.  The secret is to push up under the panel while you try to open it.  My older Lux is much easier to use and operate compared to this guy although this display is much bigger.  One issue I notices with the display is that the AM/PM indicator is on the very edge of the screen making it hard to read.Overall, there are a lot of little things that add up to drop this score down to three stars.  Although I enjoy Lux products, my advice is that you chip in the $20-$50 so that you can get out of the low end budget model.

title: Smart thermostat
author: Margaret P.
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is a good quality electronic thermostat that is easy to install.  it is somewhat confusing to program initially, but provides separate weekday and weekend settings with two or four different periods each day to allow for energy savings and comfort.  The backlit display is easy to read in the dark.A nifty feature is the ability to require a code to prevent unauthorized fiddling with the temperature.  There is of course a temporary override of the programmed temperature and there is also a vacation feature.

title: Easy to install and program, and looks good, but several downsides.  Will be replacing with another brand.
author: Eagle Eyes
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: UPDATE:  So, after using this for quite some time I have decided to update the review.  The thermostat does not seem to have the DST feature built in.  I accidentally noticed the time was off by 1 hour.  I was fully expecting the thermostat to auto adjust DST.  Additionally, the front flip cover that provides access to most controls is way too "sticky".  On a couple of occasions I pulled the thermostat off the backplate trying to open the cover to get access to Cool - Heat slider.  I removed the cover completely but now it does not look as neat - a feature I liked about it.  I am thinking of replacing this thermostat with a touch-screen Honeywell or Emerson Sensi soon.ORIGINAL REVIEW:  TX9100U was easy to install and program.  I took a picture of the old RiteTemp thermostat's connections before disconnecting it, so I knew which wire was which.  I also labeled each wire with included stickers.  LUX looks more elegant on the wall than the old bulky RiteTemp it replaced.  You may consider getting a backplate because the wall faded less under the old thermostat than it did around it.  fading was not that noticeable on a light beige wall, but maybe more noticeable with other colors.  Programming was easy and almost completely intuitive.I used the thermostat for some time and clicking is annoying.  There are a few clicks per cycle and they are quite audible.  The thermostat is in the living room and clicks can be heard over the TV noise.  Old RiteTemp thermostat had only two clicks - one for on and another for off.  I also do not like that Cool flashes on the screen while AC is running, but that is not a big deal.I neither love nor hate this thermostat.  It is probably a good value for the price, but I may end up replacing LUX TX9100U with something that is less noisy.  I think Honeywell has thermostats figured out.  I have Honeywell RTH7600D, and I like it.

title: Terrible product, programing is difficult to do
author: Gerard J DeLeo
info_3: Terrible product, programing is difficult to do, hard to adjust and it?™s impossible to get customer service on the phone. I spent a full day calling them and if you can believe it the customer service line is answered by a fax machine. So here I am sick in my house and my Thermostat kitcks into something called ?œstage 2?meaning the temperature in my house is 50Â° and the temperature outside is 20.Horrifying.  I should send them the hospital bills if I have to  get admitted for pneumonia.

title: I don't recommend - drains battery in days! Not reliable.
author: Tara B. Kelly
info_3: I purchased this in October 2016. Worked fine until October 2017 when I also got the "Lo" message and the unit started draining fresh DURACELL batteries within days.  Keep changing them but it keeps happening.  Apparently there are many other experiencing this issue too. Replacing today with a Honeywell.  I do not recommend this product.

title: Exactly what I was looking for.
author: Summer Girl
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: My landlord installed this thermostat for me, as I have never installed one and didn't want to chance messing it up.  He seemed to be done quickly, and told me that it was an easy procedure.I was looking for a thermostat that I could program for the heat to come on before I get out of bed in the morning, and turn on before I came home from work at night.  This one fits my needs!  I like that you can set it for different times on the weekends.  It is easy to program, and use.  I like it.  I was looking for a basic thermostat and this is it!

title: One Star
author: DOC
info_3: WHAT A PIECE OF CRAP

title: Very good, but looks/feels very cheap
author: Values Privacy
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is for the TX500Uc model.I would give this 5 starts if it didn't feel so cheap. If I don't close the door just right, it gets stuck open and feels like it'll break. The manual is a sheet of paper (full manual online). It looks cheap on the wall.That being said. This is a really good thermostat functionally.There is an insert that says if I have "a" or "b" in the suffix, then this is a newer model that has "Heat/Cool Cycle Duration" setting.Well the one I have has "c" in the suffix.Ugh so they didn't update the insert after updating the model.And after a bit of confusion trying to find the "Heat/Cool Cycle Duration" setting in the same insert, I realized it's the "Temperature swing" setting in the manual.Ugh. Call it the same thing in all the papers. I'm already nervous about installing it wrong...The idea is great, you can have the system come on more often (as opposed to less often and runs longer). This is great if you want to keep the temperature more consistent in rooms that the thermostat isn't in. Basically adjust how far off the desired temperature you want to allow it to be. But it's a setting number and not a temperature, so you have to see how it behaves and adjust.

title: Very nice for the price
author: Kristine Hale
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: As much fun as the Nests and Smart thermostats of the world are, sometimes you just want something that works great, is easy to use and works without any hassle. Lux Products TX500U is all that. It claims to work with almost any system, and I can confirm that it at least works with a cobbled-together, 80 year old wiring, pain in the butt, HVAC system. It also claims that it takes 15 minutes to install, and it took me (with my very limited knowledge) 12 minutes.For an affordable thermostat, this thing is loaded.Multiple settings (4 settings per day, separate weekday and weekend setting), easy to read, filter monitor, out of the home energy savings, installs with just a screwdriver and has a nice, clean look on the wall. It als comes with multiple installation options so you can adjust it to fit your own home.There are drawbacks, of course. The control buttons don't light up, just the display face, so it is a little hard to mess around with at night. The unit also feels kind of cheap, but it doesn't look cheap on the wall, so just don't touch it ;)For the price, it really is a very nice control and it has been working reliably for me for several days, keeping my home at must the right temp despite needing to switch back and forth between heat and cool. Crazy fall weather.

title: Good thermostat
author: C. Hamilton
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: We like this thermostat. It looks pretty large in the picture, but it actually ended up being a little smaller than our old thermostat. The numbers are nice and big and can be seen across the room.The first night we installed it, we thought we had the temperature set to 70 degrees. We woke up to a hot and sweaty 85 degrees. Apparently we had set the temperature for am and it had changed to the "evening" set temperature before we woke up. We promptly went online and downloaded the manual after that. If you google the brand name and model number, it is easy to find the manual.After skimming the manual, I found it somewhat confusing. My Husband however was able to figure it out and program the temperatures. If we do want to change the temperature, we learned to hold down the hold button to keep it where we set it.The front plate does stick and is hard to open. However, you don't need to open it on a daily basis. Once we had it programmed, we don't really open it anymore.Overall, we like this thermostat. It has some flaws, but it is nice looking and functional. The best part is definitely the programing feature. It should be improving our power bill for next month.

title: One Star
author: R. G.
info_3: Ours lasted 18 months, then the battery issue that these have got us.

title: Stay Away!
author: S. M.
info_3: JUNK.  Our house has three zones all controlled by individual thermostats.  I replaced all three honeywell old manual thermostats with three of these Lux TX1500Uc thermostats.  For the first year they worked great... after about a year, they all started to flash that the batteries were low.  I attempted to change the batteries in all three units with Duracell alkaline batteries (per their manual - use only Duracell or Energizer alkaline), and in all three cases, they all still indicated that the batteries were low.  Batteries were brand new, expiration 2025 and fully charged (checked with a multi-meter).Our house has no AC, and oil boiler for heat (only 2 wire setup required)... will try for replacements from Lux since these I believe have a 3-year warranty... perhaps a bad batch??  But if you look through the Amazon reviews, you'll see plenty of reviews stating similar issues with this thermostat.

title: Supply chain sent the wrong model versus what was listed and bought!
author: Random Consumer
info_3: I'm not sure how to put this in. 1 star not for the product, I'd go a 3 or 4 even with the slight high-pitched buzz when the display screen is on, but for not getting the correct product. How can I rate my Amazon experience separately?Back story: I ordered this thermostat and installed it without a thought beyond checking that the jumper was on electric and not gas. I have a heat pump and was assuming this was covered. The instructions mentioned nothing to the contrary so away I went. What I didn't realize until winter when our new tenants asked about the MASSIVE electric bill and an HVAC tech sent a picture of the missing dip switch (as noted in the manual I downloaded for this model) that it was a TX1500U*c* and not heat pump compatible. They were running on electric heat the entire time. Awesome.The one I ordered was clearly a TX1500U and clearly stated HP compatible so basically, I received the wrong product. It looks like Amazon simply sent me the wrong one somehow. The thermostat worked well for what it is with air conditioning and electric heat but was not what was ordered. I hate to slam the unit itself but something is wrong with the supply chain. Were they boxed up wrong in the case that Amazon pulled from? Did Amazon simply stock them improperly or pull the wrong one? I don't know. Sigh.If someone relevant sees this and can take it up to make sure things are correct in the supply chain, I can drop the review or bump the stars. Thanks.Otherwise, double-check that you received the proper model and not the cheaper TX1500Uc like I did despite paying for the heatpump version!

title: Excellent Customer Service
author: Tricia
info_3: I purchase this programmable thermostat a year ago an had a problem with the lo-battery indicator not resetting after I replaced the batteries.  I emailed the service department describing my situation and that I followed their instructions on how to reset it, and received an email back saying a replacement would be mailed out in 2-3 business days.  Didn't have to argue, prove purchase or anything other than to email them serial numbers on the unit and a new one was on the way.  Very happy with outcome, it's nice to see a company stand by their products.  Will buy again, if needed.

title: Great for the price
author: Steve K
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: I live in a rental unit - but that doesn't stop me from swapping out their terrible fixtures with some of my own!  I've swapped out light switches with dimmers, crummy low-flow shower heads with nice big ones that have much better water pressure, etc.  I plan on taking it all with me when I leave - it's easy to swap out stuff like that.  Hence my desire to replace that god-awful 1980s thermostat with something like this - a digital, programmable modern-day thermostat.I swapped out thermostats before.  They're about as simple as it gets.  At least for old homes - there's only two wires to worry about.  Kill the power to the unit (use a power or line tester if you have one - they're cheap and come in handy) and stick the wires in the correct holes.The instructions were a little wordy / confusing.  It includes one giant sheet that shows all these different possible configurations of wiring your home may have.  If you've never done this before, it may be a little daunting.  But I managed to figure it out without destroying my apartment, so you probably will too!This unit has some neat functions to it, but they're not exactly intuitive.  Me, I don't need them;  I live alone (for now) so I just set it to the temperature I want when I walk in the door.  I turn everything off when I leave.  I told a friend recently that I do this, and they told me it may actually be cheaper to leave it on all day, rather than have the system fight to bring the temperature down at the end of the day.  So, with that said, I'll take a deeper dive into the programming features.  I like things to be simple - dead-easy to figure out and use.  This device is a little on the complex side, being that you have to hit several selections just to choose one option.  BUT - for me?  For the price?  I like it.  It's cheap - and it's modern - and it shows the temerature of my apartment versus the temperature I want it to be.  Living alone, I don't need much more.  I was hesistant to use this thermostat being that I'd never heard of "Lux Products" before - but I'm pleased with it.

title: Noisy garbage
author: Jordan Low
info_3: Garbage.  Not only do fresh new Duracell batteries trigger LO Batt... But there is a good awful high pitch noise everytime the backlight turns on.  Posting a video so noone else suffers with this trash.  Will be returning this.

title: Worked very well for one and a half years on ...
author: KOVARIKS
info_3: Worked very well for one and a half years on one set of batteries. Now it is going through a set of batteries in less than a week.

title: Easy to install and works perfectly!
author: Hans Castorp
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: Sure beats my 40 year old (disposable) thermostat!  Unfortunately, I was never accused of being a handyman! But I live in a 40 year old condo, which until recently had the original (40 year old) thermostat. Usually that worked OK I think, even if the markings on it were frankly  unreadable from age. So after some light-weight instruction reading (even I could figure it out), I installed the new Lux model, and it is not only is easy to install, though admittedly I was nervous about removing the old one. I can read the temperature across the living room, since it is numerical, as shown in the picture. But the temp seems quieter, and easier to move around. True, so far there been nominal use, since the temperature hovers between about 60 and 80 inside and out. In any event when the inevitable cold weather rolls along, I'm sure this new thermostat will be like a match made in heaven for me!

title: Setup is a bit tedious
author: Paul Avery
info_3: I bought this elsewhere, but Amazon is my usual place for comments.  There seem to be 2 models with almost the same model number, one with an "a" appended.  The one I bought is the TX500Ua.  I think the only difference between the two might be whether the programming is done with buttons or dip switches, but I haven't checked that.  Mine is programmed from the front panel with a button sequence.This looks ok so far, but the programming mode only remains for a few seconds before dropping out.  Perhaps the programming mode sucks up huge amounts of power, and that would explain such a design.  Probably not though.  I finally wrote down ahead of time all of the selections I wanted so that I did not have to read the instructions while making the settings.It's also packaged in one of those annoying unopenable clamshell packages, though I did manage to open it.  :-PAdditional comments:  After my grousing here, I got the thermostat installed OK, though I did select the wrong wiring diagram at first (one that assumed a common 24 volt transformer rather than the two separate ones, one for heating, one for cooling, that I happened to have).The thermostat seems to work fine and seems a good deal.One of the setup items is is "System Cycle Duration," something that sets the minimum length of time from the beginning of one "on" cycle to the next, or at least I think that's what it does.  I could not understand why one would want such a setting, as I figure a thermostat should come on when the temperature drifts away from the setpoint by some amount (which I don't believe is configurable) and then cut off when the temperature is back in range.  Whatever the time between one off-to-on transition and the next needed to maintain the temperature seemed irrelevant.  Adding to the confusion is that the programmed value is described in terms of "times per hour," which it is not.  I did not find anything on the Lux website explaining this setting but only a description of the setting itself.
