I believe it defaulted to something like "20," meaning I believe a minimum time of 20 minutes between the start of one "on" cycle and the next, never mind what the temperature might be.  After some internet searching, all I could come up with was that this would allow someone with perhaps an improperly sized system inclined towards "short cycling" to extend the time from one on cycle to the next.  I still find it a bit confusing, but it might be handy in some circumstances.  This cycle duration setting is available for both the heating and cooling sides, as well as an "emergency" cycling setting that seems useful only for a heat pump's secondary heating arrangement.There is also a "Delay Time" setting that I assume or hope overrides the "System Cycle Duration" setting, but I could not tell whether that was the case.  The "Delay Time" setting is important to prevent cycling a compressor (a/c or heat pump) back on before the compressor's discharge and intake sides have more or less equalized so that it does not attempt to start against a high head pressure.  I would think the 5 min default value for "Delay Time" is best left unchanged.With these things in mind, I think I will change my "System Cycle Duration" to some value like 10 (a minimum of ten minutes between each on state) on both the heating and cooling side and see how that works.

title: Landlord approved - solid value, easy to use and consistent
author: AnAmazonCustomer
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: Owning rental properties for the past 15 years has taught us a few things about practical, easy to use and reliable home improvement projects. Here in Florida we tend to install heat pumps with emergency backup and an outdoor AC condenser. We've purchased much more expensive thermostats in the past...with the end result of tenants calling at all hours of the day and night because they couldn't figure out how to set the thermostat. Clearly what was needed was an easy to install option (this one is) that is easy to use (check) easy to understand/modify (check), consistent for every house (check) and affordable (check). We first tried a Lux about ten years ago and have been using in rentals since that time.

title: Good at first. Did not last.
author: RLW
info_3: After only a couple of months the product is malfunctioning. It will loose the time on the clock and fall back to its default settings. I have replaced the battery's twice but every few days it happens. What a pain.

title: Expensive for short life span
author: Baltimore guy
info_3: Worked about a year then get a low batt message that does not go away.  Tried new batteries and resetting the thermostat.  Poor quality product

title: No "previous" button = MUCH time is needed to program this. Hope you have time to kill. I do not.
author: DEREK D.
info_3: I'm sure this thermostat will do what it's supposed to do however, my issue is with the programming function.  The time it takes to program (once you figure out how, as the printed instruction is vague) is appx 15-20 minutes. I ordered 6 of these and programmed them for my church, so I got the hang of it after the first one and was able to go through these as fast as it could possibly be done.  Problem is, there's no fast way to do it.Each day has 4 time settings in which you can change the time you'd want the temperature to change. So from Monday morning to get all the way through the week to get back to Monday morning, you will have to click "Next" 8 times to get through each day x 7 days, so to get back to Monday = 56 times. That's a lot of clicking = time consuming.  So if I forget to change the time for Wednesday night I want the Air or heat to come on, I have to click "Next" 55 more times to get back to where I need to change the time. If there were a "Previous" button, I click it once and I'm there.  This would make programming much MUCH less time consuming.I would've given this a 5 star rating if there were a  "Previous" button.

title: Besides this quality issue the unit is not all that great to use especially in the middle of the night ...
author: Paul
info_3: Have had other lUX units and they work for a while then stop. The 1500 is flashing LOW BATTERY and despite putting in brand new fresh alkaline batteries it continues to flash LOW BATTERY.Besides this quality issue the unit is not all that great to use especially in the middle of the night when it has not kept the temperature where you had it set.Don't waste your money on this one.

title: High Hopes but Dissapointed
author: E-Kat
info_3: Ordered two TX9100U thermostats from Lux to control a dual zone home (received a TX9100Ua, which may be part of my issues).  I was especially attracted to all of the functionality that came with the unit (can adjust each of the 7 days, 4 set points per day, chose a delay time, etc).  Unfortunately one key item that the thermostats do not allow you to control is the swing setting.  This would be fine if the swing setting default was programmed correctly; however, the a/c will randomly come on when the room temperature is below the set point and other instances where the a/c will not come on even when I manually put the set point several degrees below the current room temperature.Everything else seems to be great (like the look, size of the display, control mentioned above, etc.), but due to this key outage, I cannot recommend the product and will be looking for two new thermostats.

title: Works great. Great customer service
author: Matt
info_3: didn't work correctly. Lux sent me the latest version. Works great. Great customer service.Update... My TX9100Uc Started flashing low batt. So I changed the batteries with new Duracells 3 times and I only get 1 of 6 bars telling me the batteries are low even tho they are new.

title: Nice but we'll stick with our honeywell
author: Becky (in NOLA)
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: Simple and straight forward installation.  Lots of flexibility in programing; 2-4 periods per days and each day can be separately programed.  Better yet, programming is intuitive and can be done quickly.  Holding buttons during setting causes values to roll through and you can go back if you over-shoot.There are some negatives.  Have to change battery from back of thermostat.  Inconvenient, but it does have a low battery indicator which is a plus.  Also the filter life is based on days, not fan run time.  During a New Orleans summer, the cooling runs a lot, but during the winter, the heat hardly ever runs.

title: Easy To Install
author: D.D
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is a budget programmable thermostat that you can get by with but it is so plain and boxy looking.  I installed this with my heat pump and it does the job.  It does not have the ease of use like most thermostats and programming is a bit annoying.  It's easy to install and you should just follow the wires you currently have on the heat pump you are replacing it on.  It helps to take a picture of the old panel wired when you remove it so you know what goes where, and in case you want to reinstall the older panel.Get it if you just want a basic thermostat.  It does the job, but looks cheap.

title: Full functioned, but cheaply built with awkward interface
author: Karl
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: You get what you pay for.  I have two Honeywell programmable thermostats that I purchased from Amazon a few years ago  -Â Honeywell  RTH7600D Touchscreen 7-Day Programmable Thermostat.  The instructions for installation and usage for the Honeywell are crystal clear and well-illustrated, programming with the touchscreen (and no physical buttons and sliders like this Lux) is extremely easy and the shell has a solid feel to it.In contrast, this Lux thermostat's plastic shell and buttons feel cheap;  you have to flip the front open and manipulate sliders and hold various buttons down - 2 seconds in one case, 5 seconds in another - to switch into modes that let you program.  The installation instructions are a bit of a joke - so many steps are omitted and so few are illustrated.  For example, the obvious step of detaching the back plate for installation is not mentioned, and it wasn't completely obvious how to do it without trial and error.  After wiring the back plate, they never tell you to push the thermostat onto it.  Not worth detailing every step that had errors or was omitted, but it wouldn't matter too much for someone who has installed a thermostat before - but for someone for whom this is their first, I just cannot recommend the Lux in comparison with the crystal clear and lavishly illustrated Honeywell installation manual - down to Honeywell's caution to properly dispose of the toxic mercury switch in old thermostats.  The PDF manuals for these and most products are online, so I recommend that buyers review them before purchasing to get a full feel for installation and operation.The display on the screen does not look like the photo with this product listing, so they must have changed the software.  The room temperature number is smaller, and there is a permanent battery level display to the right of it in the shape of a battery with a %-sign next to it.  Because my batteries are new (not included), it looks almost like a large black "1" to the right of the room temperature.  Ugly, confusing and unnecessary.Granted, this Lux TX9100Uc is half the price of the Honeywell - and for that I can excuse the cheap plastic, but not the poor instructions and software (firmware).  If you're in a cool-only and/or heat-only climate and on a tight budget, I'm sure you'll find this fine.  If you're in an area that needs heat in the morning and air conditioning in the afternoon, you'll want to look at the Honeywell or other thermostats that can handle multiple modes automatically per day, as this Lux can only be in heat or cool mode based on a a slider switch behind the hinged front panel.UPDATE 11/2/14:  This TX9100Uc is not "daylight savings time" aware.  My old Honeywells, mentioned above, automatically set themselves back an hour last night, but not this Lux.  I see now that it isn't mentioned as a product feature, although another Lux product has it.  Another reason for me to not particularly recommend this thermostat.

title: Would not recommend any Lux product
author: Fudge Mutator
info_3: Lasted a little over a year and then flashed low battery.  replaced battery and it still flashed Lo Batt.  Couldn't program it initially then eventually (coulple of days) it didn't turn on the heat.  Would not recommend any Lux product,  so I bought a Nest

title: Worked great for me!
author: Steve J.
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: Not a bad thermostat but rather cheap looking. This is an upgrade from the one we used to have-it was an old round one that when you set it at 72 you got 4 degree cooler. I had a neighbor help me get it set up and it was suprisingly easier than I thought it was going to be. The best part is being able to look at it and it gives you an accurate temperture.  I set it at 71 and it stayed at 71 which was a nice change from having to constantly screw with my old one.If you are looking for a low cost thermostat I would go with this one.

title: I have it programmed to let the house cool down and night
author: Ian House
info_3: I'm using the thermostat to control my Hampton GCI60 pellet stove.  I have it programmed to let the house cool down and night, and warm things up an hour before we get up in the morning.  The stove uses a millivolt thermostat connection so the thermostat requires batteries to run.If you spend a while programming with the back light on, the thermostat temperature will read high for a few minutes.

title: Not worth it.
author: Mary
info_3: We were very disappointed. This thermostat is over engineered. Not easy to set and program like a Honeywell. Would not purchase another one.

title: easy to install and easy to program
author: Phillip Collins
info_3: we replaced three Honeywell thermostats we had with this one.  the Honeywell units didn't have a filter reminder, and they had a very noticeable double-click when the thermostat turned on or shut off.  while this might not bother some folks, it was literally waking us up at night.  this unit does tick, but much less noticeable.  these were easy to install and easy to program

title: Easy to install and excellent performance
author: Carroll Colby
info_3: Easy to install and excellent performance. If you are replacing an old 2-wire thermostat, in which your hot air furnace blower only comes on from the furnace, you cannot use the manual blower function on this thermostat without installing a 3-wire connection from furnace to thermostat. I look forward to doing so and using this function on the new thermostat.

title: Wonderful!
author: Kirstein Howell
info_2: Pattern: 5-2 Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This thermostat has been a welcome change in my home. I had been planning on switching my ancient dial thermostat for a long time, so this was perfect. Installation was easy and, thought we haven't needed the heat yet, it will be nice to not have to turn it down at night and up again in the morning. Installation said 15 minutes - if I don't count the time it took to find the right breaker to turn the power off, it would have been about 15 minutes. Overall, I recommend.

title: Great product for the money
author: Red
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: This is the third Lux thermostat I've used, and a brand I would purchase over competitors if I was going specifically for value.  For the money, this is an excellent feature set, and it appears to be built as well as the older Lux models I've used with great reliability.Installation was easy, using the typical screw placement and housing shape.  Build quality is good.  It doesn't have the feel of more expensive brands, such as White Rodgers, but it's still a good product.  In this model, you can skip the AA battery if you have a 24v common wire.  If you don't, the battery should last over a year.The screen is very easy to read with a nice large temp display I can see from across the room.  Programming is dead easy to do, and you can program each day.  My last lux had a temperature range setting so that your home could be in a wider range of temps if you wanted to save on equipment wear and tear (it would cool it down to a few degrees below the setting and let it get to a few degrees above the setting before starting the equipment).  This model instead lets you change the time between these cycles.  In effect it's not that much different and it lets you directly control this aspect instead of taking a roundabout approach.  There's the typical filter replacement indicator, which is a great idea.  Finally, you can set this model up to have your home cool by the appointed time (it starts early based on how long it takes to cool your home).In other words, it's quite a feature set for the price of a barebones thermostat.  Basically a no-brainer if you're trying to save money.  I have noticed that these programmable thermostats make a real dent in the power bill, so given the value conscious goal of these products, it's nice to see a model that is a great value in and of itself.

title: Very poor quality.  Broke after a year.
author: heinrichduesseldorf
info_3: Poorly made.  The cover which exposes most of the controls is very difficult to remove and often lead to pulling the entire unit off the wall.  That and periodic failures to start even when the temperature was out of range were livable.  I give it only one star because after a year of ownership the batter connectors started to fail making the unit think it was out of batteries.  I was able to eek out a few more months by jostling the batteries to get them to reconnect, which forced me to reprogram the unit b/c there is no memory when changing the batteries, but now even that doesn't work.  So now after about a year I'm forced to buy a new thermostat.Save yourself the time, effort and cost and skip this one.

title: Straight forward installation of a slightly better than standard thermostat
author: iiiireader
info_2: Pattern: 7-Day|Vine Customer Review of Free Product( What's this? )
info_3: My husband has installed thermostats before in our previous homes.  He said that replacing our existing thermostat in our current home with this one was straight forward.  Before installation, he double checked the LUX website just to make sure there would be no issues. He observed that the LUX product support website says that this model, the TX9100U is discontinued.  It works for us, but may not be around much longer.

Programming it is a bit of an ordeal, but nothing too bad. If the unit works with your system, it is probably a great deal.

title: TX 9100U
author: Gerald
info_3: The unit is cheap but it is a mess. I had the tx 9000 and it worked like a charm, but it finally went bad so I decided to replace it with the tx 9100U. Big mistake. It does not read the temperature correctly, it does not cycle correctly as it short cycles, so you have to lie to it to make it work and even then it has a mind of its own. Using the air side it comes on about 3 to 4 degrees before programmed and shuts off 2 degrees before it is supposed to come on. So you have to lie to it. The heat is the reverse. The one good thing I can say is that customer service did respond quickly both by email and home phone, but this unit is what it is and they could not make it do right so I do not recommend it. There are some adjustments to compensate, but they cannot correct the unit totally as they push the unit too far the other way. One more thing. The instructions do not all come with the unit. You have to go on line and download the rest of them so stay away from this unit.

title: Very easy to install and works well
author: uktravailer
info_3: I wanted a simple to install thermostat to replace the aging, mercury switched Honeywell items that control our heat and cooling. After researching I decided that a simple weekly timer is good enough, and certainly better that what we had originally. The RTH221B shows the current temperature and can be set to adjust the temperature when you wake, leave, return and night. It is simple to use with 15 minute increments.Installation says "15 minutes or under" and I found this to be true.To install:  Turn off power to furnace and thermostat (although it is a low voltage feed, you MUST still do this)  Unscrew the original thermostat from the wall but leave wires attached  Check the color of the wires and which terminals they attach to on the original (look for small letters W,R,Y,Rc etc)  Mark the wires (if needed) with the stickers provided in the package  Unhook wires from the original  Remove backing plate from new thermostat, thread wires through hole and place against wall  Attach backing plate using screws and wall plugs provided  Put 2 x AAA batteries(NOT supplied)in the faceplate  Attach previously marked wired to the matching terminals at the back of the faceplate  Snap faceplate onto backing plate  Read instructions for setting time and programs  Turn power to furnace back onPros: cheap, easy to install, good instructionsCons: would have been nice to include 2 x AAA batteriesOverall a good buy. I fitted one as a test and then bought 3 more.

title: Doesn't light up, get one that does.
author: B. Kinzey
info_3: Works fine but it's really annoying that the display doesn't light up. Didn't know that when I bought it and after having used it I can't recommend buying one without the light function.ETA:After a year, I don't like it. I really just need an on/off that I set a temperature for. I thought it would be nice to be able to program it as an option. Unfortunately one HAS to program it. It's not an option. It does have a temporary mode but at some point that resets to default. An example, I have a default of 68. I set a temporary of 64 for overnight. I'm not sure when it reset but when I woke up the heater was running at 68.So, if you need set times and set temperatures for the whole week this will work but if your use varies you will do a lot of reprogramming.I'll be buying a set the temp and turn on or off thermostat.

This is a pretty basic (budget friendly!) programmable thermostat and works well for our needs.Just an FYI, we had a thermostat that you could program by the day AND time (ie Monday at 1pm set it to 70*, Tuesday at 1pm we set it to 65* etc)--which is nice if you only work a few days a week or something and actually there to enjoy the heat. author: Pam
info_3: My husband and I installed this thermostat and both really loved it!  We used to get up to a cold house (because the thermostat was turned down low for the overnight) but with the digital thermostat, we can set it to kick the heat on 30 mins before we get up so it's warm.  It's then set to keep the temp down while we're away and again... the heat comes on 30 mins before we get home.  The great thing is that we're never cold...and we saved approx. 20% on our oil bill.  And replacing the thermostat was the only change we made.

title: Good Value, Poor Documentation
author: GLS
info_3: I replaced an old Honeywell mechanical thermostat with this Honeywell RTH221B1021/A 1 Week Programmable Thermostat. (I mention the exact model here because these reviews appear to include reviews for various other models, a practice I feel defeats the purpose of a review). The thermostat seems to be well enough constructed and functions as advertised, that is, is programmable for a single day in four selectable time periods and that day is replicated identically for each day of the 7 day week, or each day of the 365 day year, if you like. I agree with some who take exception to the description "1 week programmable". It should read "daily programmable",  but for a retired person like me, it's perfect. The controls are very intuitive and ingenious in their simplicity. Set it and forget it, unless you want to alter the temperature for an indefinite time period, then just adjust the temperature on the display to the desired target temperature and press the "hold" button. To revert to the original program, simply press the "run" button. This review would have earned five stars had the thermostat come with any wiring instructions whatsoever. The adequate operating manual talks about programming only. I believe the only other instructions said to hook it up according to the color codes used for your previous thermostat, which is ludicrous. Mine is a two wire heat only system and there was nothing I could do but surf the internet for wiring color code conventions and verify I had the right connection terminals with an Ohm meter. Not a big inconvenience given the low price, but still, shame on you Honeywell!

title: Honeywell RTH221B1021/A Thermostat
author: Chuqeaux is an Amazon Customer
info_3: Okay, stay with me until the end...I had two A/C units (and two separate blowers) with the old "dial-type" thermostats.  They worked but were hard to adjust precisely.  Thus, I purchased two of these for a DIY installation.I had already checked the wires coming into the old thermostats and determined that it was the standard 4-wire setup that I was expecting.  However, when I installed the new thermostat, it didn't work correctly.  The outside A/C compressor unit would kick on and I would feel the cooler air, AND, the compressor would kick off when the correct temperature was reached.  HOWEVER, the blower would always run.Since the old "dial-style" thermostat worked correctly, I assumed the new thermostat was at fault.  I then installed the second NEW thermostat and found both had the same condition - the blower ran continuously.  I garnered up my fortitude and tried to install one of the new thermostats on my second A/C.  On this second unit, it worked perfectly meaning that my first A/C and/or blower had an issue.  I ended up calling a HVAC guy to come out.  He found a blower relay that was not working.  We were not sure why the old "dial-type" thermostat had ever worked.The bottom line is that, after programming this thermostat, I've not had to touch it again.  It works and works great.My wife says this experience should have taught me about assume.  Ass-u-me can make an ass out of u and me.

title: Very poor temperature regulation.
author: A. Carey
info_3: This item was easy to install, and its programming protocol is fairly easy to follow (but not streamlined).I have two issues with this thermostat (one that is probably more about me, and one that is clearly a product issue):(1) I thought a 1 week programmable thermostat would give me the option to program different temps for different days of the week.  This is more accurately a thermostat that can be programmed for a one-day schedule that repeats indefinitely.  Perhaps, I'm just not sharp enough to understand thermostat designations.(2) This thermostat does not well-regulate temperatures,  I suspect that the thermometer portion of the thermostat is not functioning properly.  For example, my thermostat is set to allow the temp to cool to 65 degrees at night, but when I came in this morning (about 2.5 hours after the temp was supposed to warm to 72), the thermometer read 55 degrees.  Within an hour, it read 66 degrees, and then 75 degrees--again the thermostat was then set to 72.  This type of regularity has been persistent.  Unfortunately, my return window with Amazon has just closed, so I will dispose of this when my replacement arrives.

title: Honeywell 1 Week Programmable Thermostat
author: Jessi
info_3: It works exactly like it should. Keep in mind that it is a ONE week program. There are four different times that you can set. You cannot set a time for each day.... meaning, I would prefer to keep the temperature a little cooler on the weekends while I sleep in but you can not set a daily different temperature. I still love it and will keep it. I just have to make sure that before I go to bed on a day that I can sleep in, I have to set the temperature to what I want and then push "hold". If that doesn't bother you, then I would totally get this. I have saved so much money by keeping the temp higher while I'm at work and I have it set to get colder an hour before I get home.

title: Works great - read the description though!
author: Jeremy
info_3: This product works great.  It allows 4 programmable temperature changes per day.  This model is only a week programmable model though, so those four changes will work for ALL 7 days of the week.  The picture here on amazon shows a clock with the day available under the time, but this is for a different model thermostat.  You can put the programming on hold at any time by pressing the hold button, so its easy enough to customize things manually on the weekends.  Installation is easy and quick!  Requires 2 AAA batteries.

title: Installed fine...
author: Lynne
info_3: I can't say much about this other than the install went fine.  It is a replacement unit on a home I am selling so the new owners will need to review it.

title: Where are the features?
author: EJ
info_3: This thermostat is supposed to be programmable for every day of the week, but it only lets me program 4 periods of one day. I can see the days on the display, but they are not functional. It is definitely an upgrade to the old dial thermostat I had in my apartment which ran constantly. It was easy to install, but I wasn't able to do it myself due to the wires being mislabeled in my original thermostat. After maintenance got it running it has made my apartment comfortable, and it has saved energy while I am out.

title: Only has one program setting
author: Rebecca
info_3: This works fine, and it was easy to install but it it only allows for one schedule to be programmed- and then applies that to all days (i.e. we can't program one schedule for week days and another for weekends).

title: this thermostat sucks. Why would you get this one it's the ...

info_3: Let's be honest, this thermostat sucks.  Why would you get this one it's the least programmable type ever.  I got it because I was moving my Nest and needed something as cheap as possible to replace it.It does work as a thermostat is about all I can say.

title: Good but should be better
author: You
info_3: I gave it a 3-star because although it is advertised as a "1 Week Programmable Thermostat,"  all 7 days are the same -- it is really one daily program that it does everyday.Better programmable thermostats allow one to control weekdays and weekends separately.  Even better ones have controls for each day.On the plus side, it does the job and is far better than the mercury switch thermostat it replaced.

title: Works well to save money
author: golfingpenguin
info_3: The thermostat is easy to install, programing. I had one for about 2 months and it work as programmed. I discover one additional advantage  during Winter storm Nemo.  We lost power to 5 days, the Honeywell thermometer is able to show actual house temperature below 50F, while my old mercury one did not.  I purchased a second one after the storm and replacing the other thermostat in the house.  I recommended it highly.

info_3: This product was so easy to install taking me under 10 minutes.  I installed it about 3 weeks ago and I like it.  The one feature I didn't pay attention too was the program.  The daily program is for four changes - set to come up in the a.m., done when I go to work, go up again just before I return home and then down again at bedtime.  This work well and I have no need to fool around with the settings.  The one thing I did not notice was a different setting for weekends.  Easy enough to hit the hold feature but I would have liked to have a program for Saturday and Sunday.
